xxl.core.collections.bags

Class ListBag<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.collections.bags.AbstractBag<E>
      • xxl.core.collections.bags.ListBag<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of the elements this bag is able to store.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Bag<E>, FIFOBag<E>, LIFOBag<E>

    public class ListBag<E>
extends AbstractBag<E>
implements FIFOBag<E>, LIFOBag<E>
    This class provides an implementation of the Bag interface that internally uses a list to store its elements.

    The performance of the bag depends on the performance of the internally used list (e.g., an ArrayList guaratees for insertion an amortized constant time, that is, adding n elements requires O(n) time).

    The cursors returned by this class' cursor and query methods are fail-fast: if the bag is structurally modified at any time after the cursor is created, in any way except through the cursor's own methods, the cursor will throw a ConcurrentModificationException. Thus, in the face of concurrent modification, the cursor fails quickly and cleanly, rather than risking arbitrary, non-deterministic behavior at an undetermined time in the future.

    Usage example (1). 

         // create a new list bag (that uses a linked list to store its elements per default)

     ListBag<Integer> bag = new ListBag<Integer>();

     // create an iteration over 20 random Integers (between 0 and 100)

     Cursor<Integer> iterator = new DiscreteRandomNumber(new JavaDiscreteRandomWrapper(100), 20);

     // insert all elements of the given iterator

     bag.insertAll(iterator);

     // create a cursor that iterates over the elements of the bag

     Cursor<Integer> cursor = bag.cursor();

     // print all elements of the cursor (bag)

     while (cursor.hasNext())
         System.out.println(cursor.next());

     // close the open iterator, cursor and bag after use

     iterator.close();
     cursor.close();
     bag.close();
    Usage example (2). 
         // create an iteration over the Integer between 0 and 19

     iterator = new Enumerator(20);

     // create a new list bag (that uses a linked list to store its elements per default) that
     // contains all elements of the given iterator

     bag = new ListBag<Integer>(iterator);

     // create a cursor that iterates over the elements of the bag

     cursor = bag.cursor();

     // remove every even Integer from the cursor (and the underlying list bag)

     while (cursor.hasNext()) {
         int i = cursor.next();
         if (i%2 == 0)
             cursor.remove();
     }

     // create a cursor that iterates over the elements of the bag

     cursor = bag.cursor();

     // print all elements of the cursor (bag)

     while (cursor.hasNext())
         System.out.println(cursor.next());

     // close the open iterator, cursor and bag after use

     iterator.close();
     cursor.close();
     bag.close();
    Usage example (3). 
         // create a new list bag that uses an array list to store its elements

     bag = new ListBag<Integer>(new ArrayList<Integer>());

     // create an iteration over 20 random Integers (between 0 and 100)

     iterator = new DiscreteRandomNumber(new JavaDiscreteRandomWrapper(100), 20);

     // insert all elements of the given iterator

     bag.insertAll(iterator);

     // create a cursor that iterates over the elements of the bag

     cursor = bag.cursor();

     // print all elements of the cursor (bag)

     while (cursor.hasNext())
         System.out.println(cursor.next());

     // close the open iterator, cursor and bag after use

     iterator.close();
     cursor.close();
     bag.close();

    See Also:
    Cursor, Iterator, IteratorCursor, Function, LinkedList, List

    • Field Detail

      • list

        protected List<E> list
        The list is internally used to store the elements of the bag.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ListBag

        public ListBag(List<E> list)
        Constructs a bag containing the elements of the list. The specified list is internally used to store the elements of the bag.
        Parameters:
        list - the list that is used to initialize the internally used list.

      • ListBag

        public ListBag()
        Constructs an empty bag. This bag instantiates a new LinkedList in order to store its elements. This constructor is equivalent to the call of ListBag(new LinkedList<E>()).

      • ListBag

        public ListBag(List<E> list,
               Iterator<? extends E> iterator)
        Constructs a bag containing the elements of the list and the specified iterator. For the most cases the list is used to initialize the internally used list in order to guartantee a desired performance. This constructor calls the constructor with the specified list and uses the insertAll method to insert the elements of the specified iterator.
        Parameters:
        list - the list that is used to initialize the internally used list.
        iterator - the iterator whose elements are to be placed into this bag.

      • ListBag

        public ListBag(Iterator<? extends E> iterator)
        Constructs a bag containing the elements of the specified iterator. This bag instantiates a new LinkedList in order to store its elements. This constructor is equivalent to the call of ListBag(new LinkedList<E>(), iterator).
        Parameters:
        iterator - the iterator whose elements are to be placed into this bag.

    • Method Detail

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Removes all elements from this bag. The bag will be empty after this call so that size() == 0.
        Specified by:
        clear in interface Bag<E>
        Overrides:
        clear in class AbstractBag<E>

      • cursor

        public Cursor<E> cursor()
        Returns a cursor to iterate over the elements in this bag without any predefined sequence. The cursor is specifying a view on the elements of this bag so that closing the cursor takes no effect on the bag (e.g., not closing the bag). The behavior of the cursor is unspecified if this bag is modified while the cursor is in progress in any way other than by calling the methods of the cursor. In this case every method of the cursor except close() throws a ConcurrentModificationException.
        Specified by:
        cursor in interface Bag<E>
        Specified by:
        cursor in class AbstractBag<E>
        Returns:
        a cursor to iterate over the elements in this bag without any predefined sequence.

      • fifoCursor

        public Cursor<E> fifoCursor()
        Returns a cursor representing a FIFO (first in, first out) iteration over the elements in this bag. The cursor is specifying a view on the elements of this bag so that closing the cursor takes no effect on the bag (e.g., not closing the bag). Thebehavior of the cursor is unspecified if this bag is modified while the cursor is in progress in any way other than by calling the methods of the cursor. So, when the implementation of this cursor cannot guarantee that the cursor is in a valid state after modifing the underlying bag every method of the cursor except close() should throw a ConcurrentModificationException.
        Specified by:
        fifoCursor in interface FIFOBag<E>
        Returns:
        a cursor representing a FIFO (first in, first out) iteration over the elements in this bag.

      • lifoCursor

        public Cursor<E> lifoCursor()
        Returns a cursor representing a LIFO (last in, first out) iteration over the elements in this bag. The cursor is specifying a view on the elements of this bag so that closing the cursor takes no effect on the bag (e.g., not closing the bag). The behavior of the cursor is unspecified if this bag is modified while the cursor is in progress in any way other than by calling the methods of the cursor. So, when the implementation of this cursor cannot guarantee that the cursor is in a valid state after modifing the underlying bag every method of the cursor except close() should throw a ConcurrentModificationException.
        Specified by:
        lifoCursor in interface LIFOBag<E>
        Returns:
        a cursor representing a LIFO (last in, first out) iteration over the elements in this bag.

      • insert

        public void insert(E object)
        Adds the specified element to this bag. This method does not perform any kind of duplicate detection.
        Specified by:
        insert in interface Bag<E>
        Specified by:
        insert in class AbstractBag<E>
        Parameters:
        object - element to be added to this bag.

      • size

        public int size()
        Returns the number of elements in this bag (its cardinality). If this bag contains more than Integer.MAX_VALUE elements, Integer.MAX_VALUE is returned.
        Specified by:
        size in interface Bag<E>
        Specified by:
        size in class AbstractBag<E>
        Returns:
        the number of elements in this bag (its cardinality).
